text: So good to be in Boston again.
Do people say that often?
I'm coming from California.

I really-- I really
do mean that.

I spent a couple of years here
as a fellow at Harvard and--

right before I
moved to Riverside,

and so I have a special affinity
just for the Boston area.

I was able to get
a lot of work done.

It's my favorite place,
and I'm just so, so
very happy to be here.
OK.

So Audre Lorde was a brilliant
poet and scholar whose writings

on race and sexism
and emotions offer

insight into what keeps us
bound despite our best efforts.

Yet her accusatory
verse and prose

do not simply leave
us stuck in shame.

Rather they allow us to
envision a better future,

and they move us to
engage in action in order
to shape a new world.

Adamant that she
didn't write theory,

Lorde instead chose to embrace
poet as her literary title,

but despite Lorde's own
thoughts about herself,

Nancy Barrino, the original
editor of Lloyd's essay

collection Sister Outsider,
was right to conclude

that Lorde's voice is
central to the development
of contemporary feminist theory.

She is at the cutting
edge of consciousness.

Now I experienced such thinking
and upon my first reading

of her essay "The
Uses of Anger."

I discovered it in 2012 by
reading philosophy journals,

articles about
emotions, and I noticed

that feminist philosophers
were taking her very seriously

as a theorist and drawing
inspiration from her argument

the anger was epistemically
and practically useful,

particularly in a patriarchal
society that teaches women not

to be angry and punishes
them when they express rage.

Now I think a lot of you
are familiar with the essay.

In the essay, Lorde
defends anger's role

in the fight against racism
from a feminist perspective.

However, as I dug deeper
into Lorde's work,

I discovered another essay on
anger entitled "Eye to Eye--

Black Women Hatred
and Anger," and it

was written two years later
after "Uses of Anger."

Yet I noticed that this essay
was rarely being taken up
by feminist philosophers.

Part of this has to
do with audience.

She wrote "Uses of
Anger" to address racism

in predominantly white
feminist circles,

and thus she originally
conceived of it

as a speech addressed
to a white audience.

Now Lorde wrote "Eye to
Eye" to address self-hatred

among Black women, and thus
its first appearance in print

appeared at Essence magazine,
a Black woman's publication.

So it therefore makes sense why
white feminist philosophers who

are majority in academic
feminist philosophy

would stay away from "Eye
to Eye" with the assumption

that there is an inside
conversation occurring,

one that may not be
none of their business.

Today, however, I want to
trouble this assumption

and argue that what
she says in the essay

is important to our overall
understanding about anger

and oppression and
love and a whole bunch
of other good things.

I also think that
analyzing the essay

will help us address three
important philosophical

and politically
practically questions.

First, what is the relationship
between hatred and anger?

Two, how does a
person like Lorde

go from a defense of anger
to a criticism of it.

And, three, what
does the essay reveal

about anger and
anti-racist struggle
despite its particularity?

Now we are not to assume
that writers are always
passioned about their subjects.

Often it is the solution
that drives them

despite the ugliness of the
matter under discussion.

And Audre Lorde admitted
that she did not
enjoy talking about hatred.

However, her work reveals that
her thinking about the topic

was quite sophisticated
and her answers for how

to escape its trappings
were practical and distinct

from suggestions
that she offered up
in her most popular essay.

Now Lorde defines hatred as that
societal death wish directed

against us-- that
is Black women--

from the moment we were born
Black and female in America.

It is a death wish
for the hated.

And it's here that her account
squares with recent work

in social psychology
that describes the action

tendency of hatred as
wishing for the elimination
of the other.

To illustrate this death wish
and ill will aspect of hatred,
Lorde cites historical examples.

She mentions Elizabeth Eckford
of Little Rock, Arkansas.

In describing her day of
integrating a Southern school

in the 1950s, Lorde depicts
the white verbal opposition

she experiences: "white
hatred running down

Eckford's pink sweater and a
white mother's twisted mouth,

savage, inhumane, wide over
efforts jaunty braids held high
by their pink ribbons."

She then references an
example of physical death wish

borne of hate when she mentions
four little Black girls

none more than 10 years of
age singing their last autumn

song in a Sunday school
in Birmingham, Alabama,

a reference to the 16th
Street Baptist church

bombing that killed four Black
girls and injured 22 others.

However, Lorde doesn't
restrict hatred to ill will.

In her view, hatred
also refers to what

she calls an emotional habit
or attitude in which aversion
is coupled with ill will.

It's ill will plus aversion
or what we call disgust.

Disgust directed
towards others derives

from our human inclination
for primitive disgust.

Primitive disgust is our natural
reaction to such triggers
as smelly and decaying things.

It creates a yuck
reaction in us and is

thought to originate from
our biological tendency

to protect ourselves
from infections.

But the aversion that Lorde
speaks to is social disgust.

With social disgust,
instead of insects,

we show an aversion
towards others

because we associate
them with the repulsive.

Lorde provides an example of
this aversion aspect of hate

when she recounts a childhood
experience on the subway.

She writes, on the other side,
a white woman in her fur hat

staring at me, her mouth
twitches as she stares

and her gaze drops down,
pulling mine with it.

Her leather gloved
hand plucks at the line

where my new blue snow pants
and her sleep fur coat meet.

She jerks her coat
closer to her.
I look.

I do not see whatever
terrible thing

she is seeing on the seat
between us, probably a roach.

But she has communicated
her horror at me.

It must be something very bad
from the way she's looking,

so I pulled my snowsuit closer
to me away from it, too.

When I look up, the
woman is staring at me,

her nose holes and eyes
huge, and suddenly I

realize that there is
nothing crawling up
the seat between us.

It is me she doesn't
want her coat to touch.

I do not understand,
but I will never

forget it-- her eyes, the
flared nostrils, the hate.

Now Lorde first assumes
that the woman is expressed

in primitive disgust
at an insect,

but she soon realizes
that she, a Black girl,

is the object of
the woman's disgust.

It is social discuss, but even
that description is incomplete.
Lorde labels it as hate.

However, ill will and disgust
not the only attitudes
involved in hatred for Lorde.

She also includes loathing
and contempt for whatever
is Black and female.

And contempt is in
other blame emotion

that responds to violations
of community norms.

Now if that's the
definition of contempt,

one might ask what
crimes could Black

women and girls have
committed to make them
targets of contempt via hate.

If contempt is a violation
of community norms

and it has to do with
social hierarchies

and if according
to Lorde we live

in a patriarchal and
white supremacist society,

then Black women will be
violators of community norms

that says that they
do not belong or hold
a status worth considering.

And they will be apt targets
of contempt as a result.

And it's for this
reason that when

Lorde attempts to give a reason
for why Black women are targets

of hate, she says,
from that moment on,

we have been steeped in hate
for our color, for our sex,

for our effrontery
in daring to presume
that we had any right to live.

That contempt
response to bad being,

that is bad character, the
contempt found in hatred

towards Black women
responds to their bad being
in another sense.

Their very existence is
considered a moral wrong.

It was a source
of this bad being

that Lorde tried to rid herself
of as a child via bathing.
She writes did bad mean Black.

The endless scrubbing with
lemon juice in the cracks

and crevices of my
ripening darkened body

and, oh, the sins of my
dark elbows and knees,

my gums and nipples,
the folds of my neck,

and the cave of my armpits,
Black women's crime

is their existence
and their belief
that they deserve to be alive.

In a sexist and racist
society, such existence

will make them apt targets
of contempt and thus hatred.

And Lorde not only
defines hatred,

but she provides
two examples of it--
racism and sexism.

And she suggests that both are
correctly perceived as hatred.

Now hatred's function
for Lorde is clear,

for it operates in her
words: "certainly to mask

and distort the beauty, which
is power, in ourselves."

The hate functions to
de-limit Black women's

power, a power that Lorde
sought to amplify, too,
and activate in her readers.

While Lorde admits that outside
hateful structures had created

barriers to delimit
Black women's power,

she thinks that a different
manifestation of hatred

has much more potential
to threaten Black women's
power and their survival.

Now if you are the target
of hate in a society filled

with misogynoir,
one might ask what

are the psychological attitudes
and social acts that one is
likely to take on and engage.

For Lorde, it is
self-hatred, and self-hatred

leads to a distinct kind
of anger and cruelty.

Now before we get to
this latter of facts,

it's important to address
how self-hatred rises.

For Lorde, she believes that
a constant diet of hatred

leaves the hated agent, the
hated woman, the hated person,

wanting to become
anything but themselves.

And this begins in childhood for
as Lorde writes: "Little Black

girls tutored by
hate into wanting
to become anything else."

And this helps explain
the Lorde's attempt

to scrub the Blackness off
of her body as a child.

Her self-hatred makes her
not want to be who she is.

She yearns and works to become
anything else but a Black girl.

Second and most
importantly for Lorde,

self-hatred leads
the hated agent

to hate those who most resemble
herself, which in this case
is other Black women.

Now there are
several reasons why
other Black women are targets.

One reason is referred to what
I refer to as myth confirmation.

If there is a
mythology that exists

about a racial group
and one internalizes it,

an encounter with another
person of the same group

can remind or amplify the truth
of the myth and hence the truth
about oneself.

Lorde thinks the other
women, other Black women

are the targets of self-hatred
because their presence is

the very embodiment
of white mythology,

and thereby it yells
out what is well

known about Black women and
their status in society.

Seeing another Black woman
confirms a well-known secret

that Black women
including oneself

are app targets of disgust,
contempt, and ill will.

Lorde states: "We cut
our eyes out sister

because she can only
reflect what everybody

has said mama seemed
to know that we

were hateful or ugly or
worthless but certainly
unblessed.

We were not boys,
we were not white,

so we counted for less than
nothing except to our mamas.

And it's here that the
contemptuous aspect of hate
appears.

Black women are the
targets of the self-hatred

not only because they can
remind each other of the myth

but because they can
reflect the hated person,

the hated agent,
the hated woman.

She writes we bear the
face that hatred seeks.

The other Black woman
is indeed like her,

and if you hate
yourself, you will likely

hate those who
most resembles you.

Lorde describes it
as such for once she

takes the white world's
estimation as Black woman

synonymous with
garbage to heart,

then deep inside she will
always believe that she
is truly good for nothing.

And it's easier to see
you as good for nothing
because you are like me.

And it's here we see that
the other Black woman's bad

being is a reflection
of one's own bad being.

The self-hatred
would not only create

psychological struggles
but produce effects

that reify the claims
of white supremacy

and halt the necessary love
needed to reclaim Black women's
power under oppression.

For Lorde, anger
becomes the vehicle

that brings about these
destructive results.

Now it must be noted that
such claims are not meant
to pathologize Black women.

To be sure, if anything
is pathological,

it is the conditions that give
rise to this kind of anger.

It is the pathological context
that engendered Black women's

anger, for, as bell
hooks declares,

white supremacy is rooted
in a pathological response
to difference.

A society that hates
Black women ever

since they were born
simply because they

insist on the right to exist
is indeed pathological.

In addition, Lorde held
an inclusive and expansive

perspective concerning
oppression and its effects.

Misusing anger is not
just a vulnerability
that Black women face.

Lorde, and the essay
"Uses of Anger"

exposes the distinct problems
that angry white feminists also

face in response to their
own racism and mistreatment
of Black feminist allies.

What she's pointing to as
Black women as a case study

is the mechanisms
and outcomes involved

when any group of people are
the targets of societal hate.

Though there will be
important differences,

hatred and thus self-hatred
will exist among the oppressed.

Her diagnosis is not just
exclusive to the Black woman
experience.
It is a message for us all.

Lorde acknowledges
that when you are

the target of consistent hatred
as expressed in misogynoir

and you internalize
the hatred, there

will be destructive effects
in your interactions

with other Black women
for the reasons expressed.

Growing up metabolizing
hatred makes it the case

that, "every human
interaction becomes tainted

with a negative passion and
intensity of its byproducts,
which is anger and cruelty.

This cruelty is a part
of the legacy of hate.

The anger is: "armed
with a powerful cruelty

learned in the bleakness of too
early battles for survival."

The harshness one might
say is part adaptive.

It can help the hated agent
to survive in a hostile world,

and this is why Lorde writes:
"to adapt and take the hate,
we become like stone".

However, it's very
clear for Lorde

that it's also non-adaptive, for
the drawback in her words is,

"you end up bruising
those closest to you."
Those who you need to survive.

The idea that harshness
can protect you forever--

and Lorde calls this myth of
self-protection-- in her words

"breeds harshness and
cruelty where what is needed
is softness and understanding."

Anger and self-hatred also
spawned harsh judgments

of other Black women,
and this judgment then

leads to a competition with
other Black women, a contest

whose reward one falsely
believes can offer
them escape from white hatred.

The invisible battle wounds
demand that the angry woman

outdo her reflection
to escape semblance

as a way to also escape her
oppressive inferior state.
This is what Lorde writes:

"We are Black women defined
as never good enough.

I must overcome that by
becoming better than you.

If I expect enough for
myself, then maybe I

become different from what they
say we are, different from you.

If I become different enough,
then maybe I won't be anymore.

If I make you different
enough for me,
then I won't need you so much.

I will become strong, the
best, excel in everything,

become the very best because
I dare to be anything else.

It is my only chance to become
good enough to become human."

Become indifferent and better
than another Black woman

is to believe to be a ticket
to the liberal conception
of the human.

Of course, this is fantastical
thinking and a futile attempt

at gaining recognition in a
white supremacist society.

But even if it
wasn't futile, Lorde

believes that the end
of white supremacy

and the dawn of
white approval are

unable to give Black
women what they need.

They, white acceptance,
in Lorde's words:

"would never satisfy our
particular Black woman's need

for one another given our
shared knowledge and traditions
and history."

Unfortunately, this kind of
anger, hatred, and cruelty
impedes on this togetherness.

Anger borne out of self-hatred
creates distance between women.

It keeps them separate,
and this distance functions

to make Black women
less like each other.

It makes me less like you,
makes you less like me,

and it's here that
Lorde interrogates
the dual potential of anger.

Anger in response
to outsider hate

can bring outsiders
and insiders closer.

This is because anger
sparks contestation,

demands accountability, and thus
provokes contact in approach.

But anger in response to
insider hate or self-hatred

where the connection
between them is problematic,

it widens the gap
between insiders.

This occurs because
of their unwillingness

to face each other's judgment,
to examine the anger.

Lorde believed that
the road to anger

is paved with our unexpressed
fear of each other's judgment,

and this road widens
their connection.

But as we shall see, closeness
is the cure to hatred,

and an examination of anger
and a move towards love

can counter self-hatred
and offer a way for women

to give each other the
gift of themselves.

So although hatred and
self-hatred are strong forces,

Lorde does think that there's a
possible way to find a way out

of them, and she
believed that it

is possible to break through
this interrogated agony

to refuse acquiescing in this
bitter charade of isolation
of anger and pain.

So what way out
does she provide?
And she provides several.

For the sake of
time and the clock

that's before me in
front of my eyes,

I'm just going to
highlight two remedies.

So consistent with
her idea that there

are uses of anger as argued for
in her essay bearing that name,

Lorde thinks that
righteous fury exists

and that there are
many targets of fury.

Examples include those who
throw dehumanizing messages

at Black women, and
Lorde is adamant

that there is a distinction
between hatred and anger

defining the latter as: "a
passion of displeasure that

may be excessive or misplaced
but not necessarily harmful.
Anger used does not destroy.
Hatred does."

Lorde does not change her
mind about the uses of anger.

Moreover, she
expresses a concern

for how hate can
make anger go wrong.

The challenge for
Lorde is how do we

keep from releasing our
angers at them upon ourselves
and each other.

So one solution she provides
is to learn one's value
and affirm one's own worth.

This entails first admitting
that there are parts of oneself

that one doesn't like
and then make friends

with those parts that are
both disliked and like.

It involves learning what
is possible for oneself

and being careful not
to reach an impossible

standard the other set
in order to make you
prove your humanity to them.

It entails recognizing one's
value and to value each other,

for it's only through
self-recognition

that one is able to
recognize the worth of others
who are like you.

It's only by learning to love
oneself can one love others.

Self-love is not about slogans
or surface appreciation.

It's about reclaiming and
empowering one's present self
and embracing the past self.

It's about, in
Lorde's own words:

"learning to love the
stormy little Black girl who

once longed to be white
and anything other
than who she was.

It's about committing to one's
survival and the survival
of other people."

Second, hated agent
must learn to be tender.

Tenderness is kindness,
patience, understanding,
and patience.

It's in contrast
to the harshness
and cruelty that anger breeds.

Being gentle with others
requires that a person at first
be gentle with themselves.

Gentleness involves
complimenting others and not

requiring perfection
from them, and Lorde

suggests that we
study this tenderness
until it becomes a habit.

So I'm going to skip over
some real juicy parts because
of time.

And so it is not my fault.
It is really not my fault.
It is not my fault.

So in the case of rage, I defend
anger at racism and racists,

and I call it
Lordean rage inspired

by Audre Lorde's account of
anger and the uses of anger.

And on my view, Lordean rage
is an anti-racist anger that

is essential to struggles
against racism because it

advertises as justice
worth as well as

the targets of injustice, it
motivates political action,

and it breaks
racial rules, rules

that are meant to sustain
white supremacy by determining

how oppressed groups should
feel, think, and behave.

However, "Eye to Eye"
suggests that it's not

enough to have Lordean rage
if one also has anger spawned

by self-hatred and thus has
yet to obtain the solidarity

and togetherness with
those who bears the face
that hatred seeks.

So I want to answer this
question before I go.

So can Lordean rage,
this anti-racist anger,

this positive anger,
sustain the hatred agent?

I believe that Lorde can
provide some insights to us.

First, Lorde notes the
anti-racist anger in response
to hatred, it can keep us alive.

It's more useful than the
hatred that it responds to,
and it can clarify differences.

However, she recognizes--
and this is her own words--

"strength that is bred by anger
alone is a blind force which
cannot create the future.

Such strength does
not focus upon what

lies ahead but upon what
lies behind upon what
created it, which is hatred."

Lorde's focus on this passage is
on the solidarity and strength

that anti-racists
can create, but she

thinks that anger
at the oppressor

is not enough to bind and
strengthen the oppressed

no matter how useful
it is for fighting
powerful oppressive outsiders.

I believe "Eye to Eye"
gives us resources
to make up for this lack.
So what is that lack?

Lorde also recognizes that
engaging in anti-racist anger

to fight hate is not
enough to give us the power
that hatred seeks to restrict.
They need something more.

She writes: "and political
work would not save our souls,

no matter how correct
and necessary that work.

Yet it is true that
without political work,

we cannot hope to survive long
enough to effect any change,

and self-empowerment is the most
deeply political work there is
and the most difficult."

Anti-racist anger
allows resisters

to engage in political
work that gives them

a chance at survival,
but it's only

when they let go of the
self-hatred and the anger

that it engenders and embrace
tenderness, self-love,

and self-worth can they
regain their power, which

is hatred's to target and
the embrace of each other

and is only in doing so are
they able to save this soul."

This is the empowerment
that Lorde defends.

And this is not to say
that political work

or political emotions are
not important or necessary.

More is needed like love,
empathy, solidarity,

togetherness, and tenderness
among community members.

It is difficult work,
but as Lorde describes,

it is the most deeply
political work there is.

So in conclusion, anti-Black
racism, misogyny, xenophobia,
anti-Semitism--

I can go on and on-- and
other forms of hatred

are on the rise in
the Western world,

and many have been
emboldened to express hate

in ways that would have
been looked down years ago.

I think every
generation thinks that.

And it's for this reason that
many people-- journalists,

political theorists,
philosophers--

have given philosophical,
practical attention
to the phenomenon.

But it's not enough to
only analyze group hatred,
racial hatred, or hate speech.

I think hatred has an
afterlife, what Lorde refers

to as self-hatred,
anger, and cruelty,

and if we do not examine
and seek to remedy them,

then even when all the racist
and sexist hate disappears,

hatred will remain as powerless
people lie in its wake.

Audre Lorde draws our attention
to how self-hatred manifests

and how it fuels a distinct
kind of anger and cruelty,

and she challenges us to
engage in the important work

of working on ourselves and
each other to combat it.

I think that we will be wise
to heed her recommendations

or witness the alternative,
power and connection extracted

from the lives of those
who need them the most.
Thank you.
[APPLAUSE]
